caption.p: Literature review on in vivo pharmacological activities of plants for antimalarial purpose. ∗

tr.td: Chemosuppression of parasitemia against Plasmodium berghei. Mice were divided in 4 groups. Oral administration of extracts (100 mg/kg/day) for 4 days. Positive and negative control groups were included.
Crude extracts of Adansonia digitata demonstrated promising antimalarial activity

Suppressive and prophylactic potentials against Plasmodium berghei. Mice were administered with two different doses (200 mg/kg body weight and 400 mg/kg body weight) of extracts for 5 consecutive days. Control groups were included.
Aqueous, methanolic extract, chloroform fraction and ethyl acetate fraction (EF)

The 400 mg/kg body weight was more effective on parasite clearance than the 200 mg/kg body weight in all groups. Both 200 mg/kg and 400 mg/kg body weight doses of EF exhibited the highest chemosuppression (% parasitemia 1.6–0.9%), (% clearance 67.9–81.7%)
EF of Adansonia digitata stem bark has potent antimalarial property

Suppressive test against P. berghei berghei. Mice were randomly divided into 5 groups and treated for 4 consecutive days with 100, 200 and 400 mg extract/kg body weight orally respectively. Two control groups.
% Suppression (negative control, 100 mg/kg, 200 mg/kg, 400 mg/kg, positive control: 0%, 61.9%, 78.4%, 91.9%, 98.8%)
The plant has potent antiplasmodial effect

Suppressive test against P. berghei. Oral administration of the test extract at a dose of 500 mg/kg body weight for 4 days. In vivo interactions of chloroquine (CQ) and the plant extracts were tested. Two control groups.
Ficus sur showed significant antimalarial activity
Suppressive test against P. berghei. Oral administration with different dosages: 350 mg, 750 mg and 1,000 mg/kg body weight for 7 days. Two control groups.
The plant has potent antiplasmodial effect

fn.p: Key to abbreviations: AQ: Aqueous; CF: Chloroform Fraction; CHCl 3: Chloroform; CQ: Chloroquine; EF: Ethyl Acetate Fraction; ME: methanolic extract; MeOH: Methanol.
